To develop efficient Pd/SnO2 catalysts with ultra-low Pd loadings for toluene combustion, nano-rod (SnO2-R) and nano-particle (SnO2-P) supports have been intentionally prepared. SnO2-P has a much larger surface area and lower crystallinity than SnO2-R, hence possessing richer surface-active O2 2- and O2 - sites. HRTEM and XPS demonstrate that only Pd2+ is formed on Pd/SnO2-P. In contrast, a considerable amount of Pd0 is formed besides Pd2+ over Pd/SnO2-R, which is highly effective to adsorb/activate both toluene and O2 molecules. It was discovered that surface Pd0 plays a more critical role than the active oxygen sites. Therefore, Pd/SnO2-R demonstrates much higher activity than Pd/SnO2-P at the same Pd loading. With SnO2-R support, 9 times less Pd could be used to get a catalyst with rival activity than with SnO2-P. The reported results might shed some new lights for people to design highly efficient catalysts with ultra-low noble metal contents. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Pd/SnO2 catalysts Ultra-low Pd loading Support morphology effect Pd valence state distributions Reactive metallic sites Toluene deep oxidation 1 Introduction VOCs from both fixed and mobile sources are one of the major air pollutants, which are harmful to the environment and human health. Catalytic combustion is an effective, feasible and energy saving way to remove their pollutions [1–3]. At present, supported noble metal catalysts are widely used for the VOCs eliminations because of their high activity at low temperatures and good stability. Due to the scarce resources and the expensive price of the noble metals, developing competitive catalysts without using noble metals, or using ultra-low content of noble metals is strongly desired, which is still a great challenge [4,5]. For supported noble metal catalysts, choosing or fabricating appropriate supports is one of the crucial elements to enhance the catalytic performance [6–8]. Over the past years, Pd-based catalysts have attracted much attention. The valence state of Pd is believed to be a vital factor to promote VOCs deep oxidation, which can be significantly impacted by the supports adopted [9–12]. Huang reported that metallic Pd particles having a big capacity for oxygen activating should be the active sites for total oxidation of HCHO over Pd/TiO2 [13]. Xie et al. [14] indicated the loaded metallic Pd nanoparticles is benefit for o-xylene adsorption and activation over Pd/meso-CoO catalysts [14]. Meng reported the Pd0 is more active than PdOx for toluene deep oxidation, because Pd0 sites are capable of activating both gas phase O2 and toluene at low temperatures, and being restored to the initial state by toluene reduction even in excess oxygen over Pd/NiO nano-catalysts [15]. Huang and co-workers have proved that the metallic Pd0 is the active species for o-xylene oxidation [16]. Besides these interesting works on suggesting that metallic Pd is the predominant active sites for VOCs total oxidation, there are still some other studies to have testified that Pd in oxidative states is critical for the reaction. For instance, when studying SnO2-supported Pd catalysts for CH4 combustion, Li et al. [17] reported that the interfacial oxygen vacancies formed between PdO/Pd and SnO2 are efficient to activate gaseous O2, thereby improving the activity. When using Pd to dope SnOx nano-layers, Domashevskaya et al. [18] observed that presence of Pd, PdO and PdO2 components, which all devote to the catalytic reaction. Eguchi and co-workers [6,8,18–22] reported that for CH4 combustion, PdO/SnO2 displayed the highest activity at low temperature, because of the strong PdO-SnO2 interaction. In summary, based on previous findings, it has been commonly accepted that the used metal oxide supports interfere the reactivity of the final catalysts evidently. Whereas, there is still some inconsistent opinions and un-clear aspects on the active Pd valence states during the reactions. It seems that Pd in different states are all functional for VOCs combustions. To design and fabricate more efficent and cost-effective catalysts with low or ultra-low Pd content, it is still necessary to clarify these important scientifc issues. SnO2 is an n-type metal oxide contains abundant deficient surface oxygen vacancies as well as active surface lattice oxygen species [23–25]. In 1970 s, Fuller et al. discovered that the synergetic Pd-SnO2 support action can promote both of its activity and water resistance in comparison with Pd/SiO2, which was further validated by Eguchi et al. and other researchers later [19,26,27]. Jiang reported the Au–SnO2 interaction has a strong influence on the activity of the surface/bulk lattice oxygen, the valence states of surface Sn atoms, and the types as well as relative concentration of surface oxygen ad-species. In addition, The Au-SnO2 (110) and Au-SnO2 (101) interfaces benefit partial oxidation of methanol, but Au-SnO2 (111) interface favors deep oxidation of both benzene and methanol [28]. Our group has discovered that nano-rod SnO2 is the most active catalyst than SnO2 having other morphologies for CO oxidation, and its reaction behavior is resembles that of a supported noble metal catalyst [29]. In addition, we have demonstrated that SnO2 nano-rods with the lattice being modified by a small amount of Al3+cations shows very good activity for toluene deep oxidation due to the improved oxygen mobility and surface acidity [30]. Therefore, SnO2 is not only a good support for noble metals, but also a good catalyst for various reactions. In this study, targeting to clarify how the abundance of active surface oxygen sites influences the Pd valence states, and how the Pd valence state distribution impacts the reactivity, two SnO2 supports, that is, regular SnO2 nano-particles and SnO2 nano-rods, have been intentionally designed and manufactured. It has been unraveled that the active surface oxygen amount is affected evidently by the morphology of SnO2, which in turn influences the reactivity of Pd/SnO2 for toluene total oxidation. Compared with SnO2 nano-particles, with SnO2 nano-rods as the support, much more active Pd/SnO2 catalysts can be accomplished, thus being able to reduce the Pd content to accomplish a catalyst with rival activity. We believe the results reported in this draft can shed some new lights for people to design efficient catalysts with ultra-low Pd content for VOCs combustion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the chemicals employed for catalyst fabrications are of A.R. The procedures for synthesizing the SnO2 supports with different morphologies are written in detail in the Supplementary Material. The supported Pd/SnO2 samples were manufactured by a regular impregnation method. Firstly, PdCl2 was dissolved into desired quantity of DDI H2O to get a stable aqueous solution. Then, the solution was measured according to the SnO2 support amount to obtain catalysts with a Pd content of 0.01 wt%, 0.05 wt%, 0.1 wt% and 0.5 wt%. A certain quantity of the SnO2 support was put into above solution with constant stirring for 2 h. If the PdCl2 solution is not enough to wet the support, additional DDI water was then added. After this, the mixture was heated in an 80 °C H2O bath, and eventually dried at 110 °C, which was followed by calcining at 450 °C in air for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. The initially obtained catalysts have some agglomeration, which were then grounded into powder. The as-prepared catalysts were named according to the morphologies of SnO2 support and Pd weight percentages. Notably, SnO2-R represents SnO2 nano-rod support and SnO2-P represents SnO2 nano-particle support. For example, a sample named 0.01% Pd/SnO2-R indicates that the SnO2 nano-rod support was adopted to support 0.01% Pd metal to get the catalyst. The Pd loading of all the samples was verified by the ICP ( Table 1). In the experimental error scope, the measured Pd contents in the final catalysts are nearly same to the planned formulations. 2.2 Catalyst characterization and activity evaluation The detailed information about the equipment, running condition, experimental processes, and parameters is listed in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SEM and TEM analysis To learn about the morphologies of the SnO2 supports, the SEM and TEM images were collected and displayed in Fig. 1. As depicted in Fig. 1 (A), (B) and (C), the SnO2-R support is composed of rod shape single crystals with a mean cross sectional side length of 260 nm, which aggregate into microsphere flowers. This indicates the SnO2 nano-rod support has been successfully synthesized by the hydrothermal method. In contrast, Fig. 1 (D), (E) and (F) indicate that the SnO2-P support prepared by traditional precipitation method is made up with irregular round shape nanoparticles with a mean grain size of 10.87 nm. In brief, the two kinds of SnO2 supports with desired morphologies have been successfully manufactured. 3.2 N2 sorption, XRD and Raman measurements The texture features of the Pd/SnO2 samples and the counterpart SnO2 supports were analyzed by N2 sorption, with the results manifested in Fig. 2, Table 1 and Table S1. For the two kinds of catalysts prepared with different morphology SnO2 support, obviously differed texture characteristics are observed, which are mainly decided by the texture properties of the supports. Pd/SnO2-P with varied Pd loadings exhibit a type IV isotherm, which is accompanied by an H1-type hysteresis loop in the P/P0 of 0.7 − 0.9, indicating that these samples possess a mesoporous structure with interparticle pores assembled by the SnO2 grains. In comparison, despite the Pd loading, the Pd/SnO2-R samples have a type II isotherm without a hysteresis loop, testifying that they have a non-porous structure, in good accordance to the single crystal structure of SnO2-R support with very low surface area (Table 1). [31] Notably, SnO2-P support and the corresponding catalysts possess much larger surface areas and pore volumes than the SnO2-R samples (Table S1). This testifies that the SnO2-P catalysts have much more abundant pores than the SnO2-R catalysts in the bulk structures, with a mean pore size around 11 nm. In summary, the texture features of Pd/SnO2-P or Pd/SnO2-R samples are the same to the counterpart supports, demonstrating that the Pd species disperses finely on the SnO2 surface and has no evident change of their texture structures. XRD was employed to probe the phase information, with the patterns shown in Fig. 3(A). The three featured diffraction peaks at (110) = 26.6°, (101) = 33.6°, and (211) = 51.7° belonging to the tetragonal rutile SnO2 phase are detected for all the catalysts. No extra peak of Pd or PdO species is observed. Considering the fact that low Pd loading (≤ 0.5%) is used in this study, it is reasonable to deduce that the Pd/PdO species scatters highly on the surface of the supports, thereby escaping the detection by XRD. [30] Nevertheless, all the SnO2-P samples exhibits obviously lower peak intensity of the SnO2 phase than the SnO2-R samples, implying that the used SnO2 supports have differed crystallinity. Therefore, the crystallite sizes are calculated in Table 1. It is apparent that all the Pd/SnO2-R samples have nearly 5 folds bigger size than Pd/SnO2-P catalysts, being well consistent with the low surface area and non-porous structure of SnO2-R nano-rod support. The structure properties were characterized for the catalysts by Raman as well. Fig. 3(B) manifests that all the catalysts show three characteristic peaks at 476, 632 and 775 cm−1, being related to the Eg, A1g, and B2g modes of rutile SnO2 phase [32,33]. Again, the peak intensity of Pd/SnO2-R catalysts is much more intensive than that of Pd/SnO2-P catalysts, verifying that the SnO2 nano-rod support is much better crystallized than the SnO2-P support. It is noticed that the 632 and 755 cm−1 peaks of 0.5% Pd/SnO2-R have some apparent shift, which could be induced by the much higher Pd loading that can generally form larger Pd particles. Usually, the larger metal particles have a weaker interaction with the supports than the smaller ones, which could be the cause inducing the shift of the Raman peaks [34]. It is mentioned that no any Raman band related to Pd species is detected, proving again the fine dispersion of Pd/PdO on the support surface, being well consistent to the XRD results. 3.3 HRTEM studies To better understand the surface features, the catalysts were analyzed by HRTEM. Fig. 4(A) indicates that only SnO2 (110) facet with clear lattice fringes of 0.34 nm is observed on 0.01%Pd/SnO2-R, no any diffraction related to Pd species can be detected, in good accordance to its ultra-low Pd loading. In contrast, Fig. 4(B) indicates on 0.05%Pd/SnO2-R, besides the SnO2 (110) facet, the (111) facet of metallic Pd0 with clear lattice fringes of 0.23 nm is vaguely observed, testifying that Pd0 is formed almost in amorphous state on this sample. By further improving the Pd loading to 0.1% and 0.5%, Fig. 4(C) and (D) prove that the (111) facet of Pd0 becomes clearer on 0.1% and 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R, possibly due to the formation of larger crystallites. On these two samples, the SnO2 (101) facets with clear lattice fringes of 0.27 nm are preferentially exposed. However, no any PdO diffraction are observed, implying that on SnO2-R support, metallic Pd0 is easy to be generated [11]. In comparison, Fig. 4(E) and (F) substantiate that on 0.1% and 0.5% Pd/SnO2-P, the exposure of both SnO2 (101) and (110) facets is observed, indicating that the samples are composed of polycrystalline SnO2 nanoparticles [35]. On these two catalysts based on SnO2 nanoparticles, different from the Pd/SnO2-R samples with the same Pd loading, the exposing of PdO (101) facet with lattice fringes of 0.27 nm is evidently perceived, which proves the PdO species in oxidized state is formed [17]. Therefore, the Pd valence state between Pd/SnO2-R and Pd/SnO2-P catalysts is different, and the difference might be closely related to the different morphologies of the SnO2 supports. Subsequently, this Pd valence state difference could impact the catalytic performance for toluene combustion activity. 3.4 Activity tests Toluene total oxidation was used to estimate the reactivity of the catalysts. On all the catalysts, CO2 is the only detected oxidation product. Notably, all the catalysts are with ultra-low Pd loading, the amount of surface Cl- should be too small to exert significant effect on the reactivity. Even if the effect of Cl- is present, the influence of Cl- should be similar and nearly equal at the same Pd loading. As exhibited in Fig. 5(A), the overall activity follows the sequence of 0.5% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.1% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.05% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.5% Pd/SnO2-P > 0.01% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.1% Pd/SnO2-P. One can see that the Pd/SnO2-R catalysts are much better than the Pd/SnO2-P catalysts at the same Pd loading. Notably, Fig. S1(A) shows that the overall activity of the pure SnO2-P or SnO2-R supports are much lower than all the Pd/SnO2 catalysts, testifying that the addition of even a small quantity of Pd can evidently improve the overall activity, due to the change of the predominant active sites. Pure SnO2-P has a little higher activity than SnO2-R, because of its larger surface area, lower crystallinity and richer surface active oxygen species. For quantitative comparison, the T10, T50 and T100, which represent 10%, 50% and 100% toluene conversion temperatures, are shown in Table 2. Apparently, at the same Pd loading, Pd/SnO2-R catalysts possess far better activity than Pd/SnO2-P catalysts. For instance, the T10, T50 and T100 over 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R are 210, 220 and 250 °C in sequence, which are 35, 50 and 50 °C lower than that over 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P. If compared between 0.1%Pd/SnO2-R and 0.1%Pd/SnO2-P, the three temperatures of the former are even lower than the latter, which drop 50, 80 and 100 °C, respectively. With the expectation to obtain competitive catalysts having ultra-low Pd contents, the Pd loading on SnO2-R nano-rod support was decreased further to 0.01% and 0.05%. Interestingly, even on 0.05%Pd/SnO2-R, the three typical temperatures are very close to that on 0.5% Pd/SnO2-P, which implies that with SnO2-R support, 9 folds less Pd can be used to get a catalyst with rival activity than with SnO2-P support. Indeed, this substantiates strongly that SnO2-R is a better support than SnO2-P to support Pd to prepare catalysts for toluene combustion. The Arrhenius profiles were collected for the samples by controlling the toluene conversion below 10% to eliminate any possible mass and heat transfer effect. Fig. 5(B) and Fig. S1(B) have indicated that the activity follows also the sequence of the overall activity. Moreover, all the Pd/SnO2 catalysts have higher activity than the two SnO2 supports. For better comparison, the toluene conversion rates (Rw and Rs), are compared in the Table 2, together with the apparent activation energies. Obviously, the Rs follow the order of 0.5% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.1% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.05% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.01% Pd/SnO2-R > 0.5% Pd/SnO2-P > 0.1% Pd/SnO2-P. When the Pd loading is the same, the Rs of Pd/SnO2-R is always much higher than that of Pd/SnO2-P. Since Rs, which is normalized by catalyst surface area, can reflects the intrinsic activity, it is reasonable to propose that loading Pd on rod-like SnO2-R can generate more active sites for the reaction than on SnO2-P. In addition, a more active catalyst generally has a lower activation energy. In brief, Pd/SnO2-R catalysts possess both enhanced overall and intrinsic activity for toluene combustion, which is believed to relate to the unique morphology of the SnO2 nano-rod. 3.5 H2-TPR and O2-TPD analysis of the oxygen property H2-TPR was adopted to analyze the redox behavior of the samples ( Fig. 6). The SnO2-P samples show a peak around 600–610 °C, and the SnO2-R samples show a peak around 720–770 °C, which is assignable to the reducing of SnO2 to form metallic Sn0 [29]. This can also be confirmed by the H2 consuming amount and O/Sn atomic ratios in Table S2. Compared with SnO2-P nano-particle samples, the reduction of the SnO2-R samples is obviously more difficult because of the single crystal structure with tighter lattice strains [29,36]. For both kinds of samples, the peak temperature decreases by improving the Pd loading, due to H2 spillover effect [37]. Interestingly, the partially enlarged Fig. 6(B) testifies that for the SnO2-P samples, besides the major reducing peak ( β peak), a shoulder peak ( α peak) below 400 °C is also detected, which is related to the typical surface deficient oxygen anions formed on the oxygen vacancies on nanoparticle SnO2 [38,39]. The H2 uptake amount of this minor peak is around 0.20 mmol g−1. However, because of the high crystallinity with nearly no surface oxygen vacancies of the rod-like SnO2-R samples, this kind of deficient oxygen species is not detected. The existence and absence of this kind of facile oxygen species on the supports may influence the valence states of supported Pd, which might eventually impact the reaction performance [7,21,40–44]. Therefore, O2-TPD experiments were carried out to further make clear the oxygen properties of the catalysts. As demonstrated in the Fig. 7, the Pd/SnO2-P samples possess two oxygen desorption peaks, with one peak below 250 °C ( α peak) and another wide peak ( β peak) around 250–650 °C. The α peak is ascribed to the desorbing of the facile surface oxygen species, and β peak is attributed to the desorbing of the active surface lattice oxygen [45,46]. In comparison, for the Pd/SnO2-R catalysts, the desorption peak of the active surface lattice oxygen shifts obviously to much higher temperatures around 500–700 °C, testifying that the lattice strain of the single crystal nano-rod is very strong. Furthermore, below 250 °C, no any oxygen desorption can be monitored because of the lack of surface vacancies in this sample. The O2-TPD and H2-TPR results are well consistent with each other, indicating that the quantity of active surface oxygen species on the Pd/SnO2-P samples is richer than that on the Pd/SnO2-R. 3.6 In-situ DRIFTS, EPR and XPS analysis of the surface active oxygen species To elucidate the nature of the active oxygen species formed on the catalyst surface, in-situ DRIFTS experiments have been designed and performed on both 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P and 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R catalysts. As to the experimental procedures, a sample was first cleaned at 400 °C in a 30 mL min−1 Ar (99.99%) feed for 60 min, and then cooled to 300 °C. After this step, a 10% O2/Ar feed was switched in the in-situ cell. Fig. 8 (A) indicates that multiple peaks around 760, 800–880 and 900–1150 cm−1 are detected. According to former reports, the peak at 760 cm−1 is assignable to the SnO bond vibration of SnO2 [47]. Whereas, the bands in 800–880 cm−1 can be attributed to the peroxide anions (O2 2-), and the bands in 900–1150 cm−1 can be attributed to the superoxide species (O2 -) [35,48–50]. Because of the much better crystallization of 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R, it displays a much more intensive SnO bond vibration peak than 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P. However, the O2 2- and O2 - peaks of 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R are much weaker than that of 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P because of the shortness of surface oxygen defects/vacancies, which are the sites to adsorb/activate gaseous O2 molecules [51]. Notably, the same experiments have been conducted for the two pure supports, which are illustrated in Fig. S2. Basically, the same phenomenon is observed, testifying that the surface oxygen properties of the two 0.5%Pd/SnO2 catalysts are mainly determined by the used supports. The active surface oxygen species of the two 0.5%Pd/SnO2 catalysts, together with the corresponding supports, was also identified with EPR. As shown in the Fig. 9(A), all the samples possess two bands at g = 2.003 and 2.005, which are assignable to the surface O2 - species [35,52,53]. With the loading of 0.5% Pd, the intensity of the peaks becomes stronger than the counterpart supports in spite of the morphology, which could be caused by the interfacial action between Pd/PdO and the SnO2 supports. It is obvious that the peaks of SnO2-P samples are more intensive than the SnO2-R samples, testifying again that SnO2 nano-particle contains more defects than SnO2 nano-rod, hence forming a larger amount of electrophilic O2 - anions. Based on the In-situ DRIFTS and EPR results, the XPS O1s spectra are thus closely analyzed. As shown in the Fig. 9(B), the O 1 s signals of all the catalysts are asymmetric, which can be deconvoluted into three kinds of oxygen anions possessing differed chemical states. In detail, the peaks around 530.6, 531.6, and 533.0 eV are related to surface lattice oxygen (O2−), peroxide (O2 2-), and superoxide (O2 -) species in sequence [31,35,54,56,55]. To exclude the possibility of the presence of surface -OH groups and H2O, the In-situ DRIFTS results of both 0.5% Pd/SnO2-P and 0.5% Pd/SnO2-R catalysts in the range of 3200 – 3400 cm−1 have been checked. Since the surface area of 0.5% Pd/SnO2-P is much higher than 0.5% Pd/SnO2-R, only its spectra are demonstrated in Fig. S3. Apparently, no evident –OH or H2O signal can be detected. It is worth noting here that all the catalysts were calcined at 450 °C, we thus believe that even if –OH or H2O are present, their amount should be marginal. The relative amount of the active surface oxygen species was quantified as (O2 2- + O2 -)/ O2− ratios in Table 2 for the Pd/SnO2 catalysts and Table S3 for the corresponding supports. Obviously, the Pd/SnO2-P samples own larger amounts of active O2 2- and O2 - sites than the Pd/SnO2-R catalysts. Considering of the fact that a Pd/SnO2-R catalyst demonstrates higher activity than a Pd/SnO2-P catalyst at the same Pd loading (See data in Fig. 5 and Table 2), it is believed that some other reasons beside the active surface oxygen species, such as the valence state distribution of Pd, should act a more critical role for the catalytic activity. 3.7 XPS analysis of the surface Sn and Pd valence states Therefore, the valence state distributions of the surface metal elements were carefully investigated with XPS. As demonstrated in Fig. 10(A) and Fig. S4(A), all the catalysts and the corresponding supports possess doublet Sn 3d peaks around 495.0 and 486.5 eV, being assignable to Sn 3d3/2 and Sn 3d5/2 of Sn4+ on SnO2 in sequence [30,57]. The Pd 3d spectra of all the catalysts are shown in the Fig. 10(B). As for the Pd/SnO2-P catalysts, two symmetric Pd 3d peaks at 337.3 and 342.5 eV are detected, which are assignable to Pd2+ species [58,59]. This indicates that when being supported on SnO2-P nano-particle support with abundant active surface oxygen species, Pd is retained in an oxidative state, which agrees well with the HRTEM observations. Nevertheless, for the Pd/SnO2-R samples, the two Pd 3d peaks are obviously not symmetric, testifying the presence of Pd species in various valence states. With deconvolution, the peaks can be divided into four symmetrical peaks at 335.8, 337.4, 341.3 and 342.9 eV, which correspond to the Pd0 and Pd2+ species, as labelled in Fig. 10(B) [3,14,60]. This testifies strongly that over SnO2-R nano-rod support being short of active surface oxygen, a certain amount of Pd is present in a metallic state. In other words, on the surface of Pd/SnO2-P catalysts, PdO is the only species, but on the surface of Pd/SnO2-R catalysts, both PdO and metallic Pd0 are present. The presence of dual Pd valence states could be one of the major reasons that Pd/SnO2-R shows better toluene total oxidation activity than Pd/SnO2-P at the same Pd loading. To confirm the Pd valence state distributions on the two types of SnO2 supports, CO adsorption In-situ FTIR and XPS tests were performed on the fresh and/or spent 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R and 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P catalysts. Fig. 10(C) shows that both the fresh and spent 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R catalysts have a strong CO adsorption IR peak assignable to CO-Pd0 at 2125 cm−1 [61,62]. In contrast, no CO adsorption is observed on the spectra of the fresh and spent 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P catalysts. Furthermore, the XPS results in Fig. 10(D) testify that on the spent 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R catalyst, metallic Pd0 species is present together with Pd2+ species. However, on the spent 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P catalyst, only Pd2+ species is detected. In brief, these results have validated the Pd0 species is present only on the Pd/SnO2-R catalysts, which can be maintained during the reaction. Therefore, the quantities of Pd0 species on the Pd/SnO2-R catalysts are estimated in Table 2 in the form of Pd0/(Pd2++ Pd0) percentage. As being observed, the percentage increases by increasing the Pd loading, in good accordance to the activity changes. When Pd loading reaches 0.1%, more than 50% Pd0 is present on the Pd/SnO2-R catalyst surface. To understand deeper the effect of Pd valence state distribution on the reaction performance, Fig. 11 (A) graphs the Rs achieved on all the Pd/SnO2 catalysts against their surface total Pd concentrations (including both Pd and PdO), which are normalized by the surface area of a sample and listed in Table 3. Notably, since Pd/SnO2-P samples have higher surface areas than Pd/SnO2-R samples, they have lower Pd concentrations than the latter at the same Pd loading. By increasing the surface Pd concentrations, the Rs goes up almost linearly. Fig. S5 (A) plots the relationship between Rw and the surface total Pd concentrations, which displays a similar trend. This indicates that the relative amount/density of surface Pd/PdO is vital for the reaction. As discussed above, Pd/SnO2-R catalysts exhibits both higher overall and intrinsic activity than Pd/SnO2-P catalysts at the same loading. On Pd/SnO2-R catalysts, a considerable amount of metallic Pd0 is present besides Pd2+ cations. However, on Pd/SnO2-P catalysts, only Pd2+ cations are generated. Therefore, surface Pd0 sites could play a crucial role to promote the activity. The Rs achieved on all the Pd/SnO2-R catalysts are thus plotted against their surface Pd0 concentrations in Fig. 11 (B). Apparently, the Rs rise linearly with the increasing of the surface Pd0 concentrations. Notably, the surface Pd0 sites can be maintained during the reaction, as testified by Fig. 10 (C) and (D). This testifies that surface Pd0 sites are very active and important for toluene combustion. Previous investigations have proven that Pd0 species, which is not fully coordinated and has empty orbitals, are conducive to adsorb and activate toluene molecules, which possesses an electron richΠ66 bonds [31,63]. Furthermore, Pd0 sites are also favorable to adsorb and activate gaseous O2 molecules, thus promoting the deep oxidation reaction of toluene [11,12,64]. In contrast, on Pd/SnO2-P catalysts, though richer quantity of active surface oxygen anions are present than on Pd/SnO2-R, there presents nearly no surface Pd0 sites, as substantiated by the HRTEM and XPS results. This could restrict the adsorbing and activating of both the toluene and O2 molecules, which eventually degrades the reactivity of the Pd/SnO2-P catalysts. Therefore, it is believed that the surface Pd0 sites play a more vital role than the surface active oxygen species on using Pd/SnO2 catalysts for toluene combustion. Indeed, this explains that Pd/SnO2-R catalysts exhibits much higher activity than the Pd/SnO2-P catalysts, especially at the same Pd loading. 3.8 Probing the surface reaction intermediates with in-situ DRIFTS In-situ DRIFTS was used to learn about the possible reaction intermediates formed on Pd/SnO2 catalysts during toluene deep oxidation. With the experiments on 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P as an example, the sample was pretreated in a N2 (99.99%) flow at 400 °C for 60 min to make the surface clean and cooled to 150 °C. Afterwards, a 1000 ppm toluene+ 40%O2 + N2 mixture feed was directed into the in-situ cells, and improved the temperature from 150 °C to 300 °C. As shown in the Fig. 12(A), multiple IR bands are observed immediately. The peaks at 1510, 1544, 1643, 1690 cm−1 belong to the typical aromatic ring vibration of toluene, [65,66] the bands at 2852 and 2917 cm−1 are due to the CH bonds of the methyl groups [67–69] and the 3068 cm−1 peak is assignable to the CH bond stretching of aromatic ring [69,70]. This testifies that the toluene molecules are adsorbed effectively on the catalyst surface. Starting from 200 °C, a new peak 1415 cm−1 appears, belonging to the vibration of CO bonds of benzoic acid, which could be one of the reaction intermediates of the reaction [70,71]. With the temperature increasing to 230 °C, three new peaks at 1075, 1146 and 1287 cm−1 show up and the intensity increases gradually, which belong to the stretching vibrations of CO bond, indicating that the benzoate and carboxylate species are formed, which could also be the reaction intermediates [65]. Meantime, two bands at 2326 and 2360 cm−1 belonging to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of CO2, [70] and multiple bands at 3200–3700 cm−1 belonging to the stretching vibrations of -OH groups [65,72] are detected, whose intensity increases by improving the temperature. This indicates that the intermediates reacted with the oxygen species to form CO2 and H2O products finally. The In-situ DRIFTS results on 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R catalyst are exhibited in Fig. 12(B), with the experiments being performed by the same procedures. In contrast to the results achieved on 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P, all the corresponding IR bands are observed either, except for some small peak shifts. Whereas, at the same temperature, all the peaks corresponding to the intermediates and products are evidently more intensive than on 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P, proving the surface reaction proceeds easier. This is in good accordance to the fact that 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R shows much better activity than 0.5%Pd/SnO2-P, due to the presence of a considerable amount of Pd0 sites being favorable to activate both of toluene and O2 molecules. 3.9 Stability and water, sulfur resistance tests Last but not the least, the stability of 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R, the optimal catalyst in this work, was evaluated at 230 °C. As demonstrated in Fig. 13 (A), the catalyst is very stable in the 50 h′ test in a dry feed, without showing any toluene conversion decrease. More importantly, Fig. 13 (B) testifies that in the presence of water vapor or/and SO2, the catalyst shows also excellent stability, with only slight toluene conversion drop from 90% to 83% after 64 h′ test at 230 °C. This indicates that 0.5%Pd/SnO2-R sample possesses good stability, potent resistance to water and sulfur deactivation, which makes it a potential catalyst for real applications in industrial VOCs eliminations. 4 Conclusions In this study, aiming to develop efficient catalysts with ultra-low Pd loadings for toluene combustion, two types of SnO2 supports with differed morphologies, that is, single crystal SnO2 nano-rods (SnO2-R) and polycrystalline nano-particles (SnO2-P), have been successfully synthesized. By using multiple tools, the surface, bulk and texture properties of the supports as well as the Pd/SnO2 catalysts have been explored in-depth. (1) SnO2-P support has a much larger specific surface area and lower crystallinity than SnO2-R. As a result, SnO2-P possesses more abundant surface active oxygen species (O2 2- and O2 -) than SnO2-R, as testified by H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS and EPR results. (2) By loading Pd on SnO2-P support, Pd is existing in merely oxidative state (Pd2+) on Pd/SnO2-P catalysts. In contrast, over Pd/SnO2-R catalysts, a considerable amount of metallic Pd0 is formed besides Pd2+, which is highly effective to adsorb and activate both toluene and O2 molecules. (3) It is revealed that surface Pd0 sites play a more critical role than the surface active oxygen sites on using Pd/SnO2 catalysts for toluene combustion. Therefore, Pd/SnO2-R catalysts demonstrate much higher overall and intrinsic activity than Pd/SnO2-P at the same Pd loading. With SnO2-R as the support, 9 folds less Pd could be used to get a catalyst with rival activity than with SnO2-P support. (4) A Pd/SnO2-R catalyst possesses not only superior activity, but also good stability, and potent resistance to water and sulfur deactivation, which makes it a potential catalyst in real industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: To develop efficient Pd/SnO2 catalysts with ultra-low Pd loadings for toluene combustion, nano-rod (SnO2-R) and nano-particle (SnO2-P) supports have been intentionally prepared. SnO2-P has a much larger surface area and lower crystallinity than SnO2-R, hence possessing richer surface-active O2 2- and O2 - sites. HRTEM and XPS demonstrate that only Pd2+ is formed on Pd/SnO2-P. In contrast, a considerable amount of Pd0 is formed besides Pd2+ over Pd/SnO2-R, which is highly effective to adsorb/activate both toluene and O2 molecules. It was discovered that surface Pd0 plays a more critical role than the active oxygen sites. Therefore, Pd/SnO2-R demonstrates much higher activity than Pd/SnO2-P at the same Pd loading. With SnO2-R support, 9 times less Pd could be used to get a catalyst with rival activity than with SnO2-P. The reported results might shed some new lights for people to design highly efficient catalysts with ultra-low noble metal contents.
coredata.dc:title: Remarkable Pd/SnO2 nano-rod catalysts with ultra-low Pd content for toluene combustion: Clarifying the effect of SnO2 morphology on the valence states of the supported Pd species and the vital role of Pd0
